title: Tumor-Derived Extracellular Vesicles Breach the Intact Blood-Brain Barrier via Transcytosis
abstract:
*Corresponding Author: marsha.moses@childrens.harvard.edu.
Author Contributions
G.M. designed and performed the experiments, analyzed and interpreted the data, and wrote the manuscript. M.A.M. designed and 
supervised the research, analyzed and interpreted the data, and wrote the manuscript. C.V.C. co-designed and assisted with high 
spatiotemporal resolution microscopy experiments. E.J.H. and J.R.P. co-designed and assisted with zebrafish experiments. N.M. and 
T.P. co-designed and performed the BBB-on-a-chip experiments. C.C.D. assisted with some of the experiments. L.I.Z. and D.E.I. 
provided zebrafish and BBB-on-a-chip models, respectively.
Supporting Information
The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/acsnano.9b04397.
Characterization of cell lines and EVs, characteristics of the static BBB model, and colocalization of EVs with additional components 
of the endocytic pathway, such as caveolin 1, EE1, and TGN46 (PDF)
The authors declare no competing financial interest.
HHS Public Access
Author manuscript
ACS Nano. Author manuscript; available in PMC 2020 April 20.
Published in final edited form as:
ACS Nano. 2019 December 24; 13(12): 13853–13865. doi:10.1021/acsnano.9b04397.
